awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Mechanisms of adaptive plasticity in speech perception
awd_abstract_narration:
Comprehension suffers when a conversation partner produces speech that departs from expectations. A strong foreign accent, a distinct dialect, or even a stuffy nose can impact the precise realization of speech. Human speech perception is remarkably flexible. Although comprehension initially suffers when speech departs from the norms of a listener’s language-community, with exposure listeners rapidly adapt and comprehension rebounds. Understanding the means by which the human brain is able to flexibly map speech to language representations promises to be important in advancing next generation linguistic theories, in building more robust machine speech recognition, and in supporting individuals communicating in non-native educational contexts. 

This dissertation research project will simulate an accent by manipulating short-term speech input regularities to determine how speech perception adapts. This offers the advantage of providing a detailed measure of how the weighting of specific acoustic speech dimensions shifts as a function of short-term speech input changes such as accent. The central hypothesis of the research, supported by preliminary studies, is that adaptive plasticity in speech communication is driven by error-driven supervised learning. Study 1 tests a prediction arising from this hypothesis: when short-term speech input regularities depart from long-term norms, supervised error-driven learning supported by phonetic category activation will result in down-weighting of secondary acoustic dimensions available for speech recognition. Study 2 pursues this prediction via a neural network that implements the algorithmic theory. Study 3 addresses whether overt phonetic category decisions are necessary for adaptive plasticity in a naturalistic listening environment without overt phonetic category decisions. Finally, Study 4 uses scalp electrophysiology to examine the level of linguistic representation impacted by adaptive plasticity in dimension-based statistical learning. In all, the project will advance understanding of how the linguistic system tackles the challenge of communication when speech input deviates from the long-term norms that established linguistic representations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Only five percent of the 7.5 billion English speakers are native speakers, leading to significant dialect and accent differences. Even among native speakers, there are tremendous dialect differences. Speech comprehension suffers when speech differs from the language-community norms of a listener. In society, this can have a detrimental impact in the context of educational settings that increasingly demand communication across diverse linguistic backgrounds. Moreover, reliable access to increasingly ubiquitous digital assistants like Alexa or Siri is limited by the systems’ poorer recognition of speech that departs from the norm of the training set used to train the systems. A linguistic theory of how communication adapts to short-term deviations in speech input can inform diverse fields because listeners rapidly adjust to accented speech, and comprehension improves. In his NSF-supported dissertation research Charles Wu investigated the cognitive and neurobiological bases of such adaptive plasticity in speech perception. The work produced several significant findings: (1) A suite of behavioral experiments manipulating speech signal acoustics across multiple English speech contrasts established a causal relationship between phonetic category activation from bottom-up speech input and the degree of adaptive plasticity observed in perception; (2) These findings inspired a novel computational model instantiating the mechanistic commitments indicated by the data. By incorporating both ‘fast’ and ‘slow’ learning mechanisms the model was able to mimic human performance in the present behavioral studies, and prior studies; (3) Another set of studies established a novel behavioral paradigm to test whether these effects reflect a true change in sensory/linguistic representations, or a change in choice-related behavioral response. The results confirmed that listeners track regularities in speech acoustics even across passive exposure, and that reliance on acoustic speech cues updates as a consequence – just as observed across overt phoneme decisions; (4) Finally, the project used electroencephalography (EEG) to examine the level of linguistic representation impacted by adaptive plasticity in speech perception. A study combining the behavioral paradigms described above with EEG measures of cortical responses evoked by the speech sounds demonstrated that accented speech leads to rapid adjustments to how the brain responds to subsequent speech, with an impact observed even in early cortical responses. In all, Charles Wu’s dissertation research advanced the mechanistic understanding of an important facet of speech perception, with real-world consequences. The project also had broader impact through Charles Wu’s near-peer mentoring of a cohort of undergraduate researchers who learned acoustic analyses, speech synthesis, statistics, programming and electrophysiology. As part of this dissertation project, Charles Wu also took a leadership role in the Department of Psychology’s outreach program, which brings local under-served middle and high schools 20-min interactive modules that are then made available online for wider distribution. Charles Wu highlighted scientific approaches to understanding language, careers in linguistics, and engagement of students’ curiosity and critical thinking using demonstrations from speech communication.
